description: Borrowed from Latin initiātus, perfect passive participle of initiō (“begin, originate”), from initium (“a beginning”), from ineō (“go in, enter upon, begin”), from in + eō (“go”).

adjectives.description: initiate (comparative more initiate, superlative most initiate)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Begun; commenced; introduced to, or instructed in, the rudiments; newly admitted.
A new member of an organization.
One who has been through a ceremony of initiation.
One who is oriented in and familiar with a topic or subject; especially, one who is an expert in it.
examples: Coordinate terms: expert, nonexpert, layperson, amateur, dilettante, journeyman, master

verbs.description: initiate (third-person singular simple present initiates, present participle initiating, simple past and past participle initiated)

examples: How are changes of this sort to be initiated?

entries.meaning: To instruct in the rudiments or principles; to introduce.
examples: Divine Providence would only initiate and enter mankind into the useful knowledge of her, leaving the rest to employ our industry.

entries.meaning: To confer membership on; especially, to admit to a secret order with mysterious rites or ceremonies.
examples: He was initiated into half a dozen clubs before he was one and twenty.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To do the first act; to perform the first rite; to take the initiative.
